questions.question: Here is the money that you lent me.
questions.description: Here the subordinate clause ‘that you lent me’ modifies the noun money. Hence it is an adjective clause.

questions.question: The person who leaves last should put the lights out.
questions.description: Here the subordinate clause ‘who leaves last’ modifies the noun person.

questions.question: This is the house that I told you about.
questions.description: Here the subordinate clause ‘that I told you about’ modifies the noun house.

questions.question: People are sleeping out on the streets because there are not enough houses.
questions.description: Here the subordinate clause ‘because there are no enough houses’ gives the reason for the action mentioned in the main clause. Hence it is an adverb.

questions.question: I knew that I should write to her, but I forgot.
questions.description: Here the subordinate clause ‘that I should write to her’ is the object of the verb knew. Hence it is a noun clause.

questions.question: Does anyone know where Janet lives?
questions.description: Here the subordinate clause ‘where Janet lives’ acts as the object of the verb know. Hence it is a noun clause.

questions.question: James replied that he was feeling better.
questions.description: Here the subordinate clause ‘that he was feeling better’ acts as the object of the verb replied. Hence it is a noun clause.

questions.question: Come in quietly so that she does not hear you.
questions.description: Here the subordinate clause ‘so that she does not hear you’ gives the purpose of the action mentioned in the main clause. Hence it is a subordinate adverb clause.

questions.question: I always knew that I could trust you.
questions.description: Here the subordinate clause ‘that I could trust you’ acts as the object of the verb knew. Hence it is a noun clause.

questions.question: The scales broke when I was weighing myself this morning.
questions.description: Here the subordinate clause ‘when I was weighing myself this morning’ gives the time of the action mentioned in the main clause. Hence it is an adverb clause of time.

questions.question: If you are ever in London, come and see me.
questions.description: This is an adverb clause of condition because it expresses a condition.

questions.question: The woman who was sitting behind the reception desk gave me a big smile.
questions.description: Here the subordinate clause ‘who was sitting behind the reception desk’ modifies the noun woman. Hence it is an adjective clause.
